Title: Explosion during discharge of liquid waste
EmergencyResponce_Descr: <p>The explosion was followed by a short fire, which was extinguished by the company’s intervention team. The cut-off supply of nitrogen to the transfer station was also sealed off. The slightly injured victims were taken to hospital for examination.<br><br>The firm’s intervention team carried out the intervention.<br>Injured victims were taken to hospital.</p>

Reasons.ItemDescription: Substances involved: greater than 5% of quantity in Column 3 of Annex I
Injury to persons: >= 1 fatalities, >= 6 hospitalizing injuries etc.
Immediate damage to the environment (according to Annex VI)

AccidentDescription: <p>On 13 September 2018 at around 14.37, an explosion took place, followed by a very brief localised fire at the North discharge pit. The explosion took place during the discharge of liquid waste from a tanker into the North discharge pit. The discharge pit is a concrete underground tank covered with a concrete lid. The remains of a previous discharge were present in the discharge pit. When the waste materials mixed with each other, a reaction occurred leading to the generation of oxygen, which formed an explosive mixture together with the solvents contained in the discharge pit. Further investigation showed that 3 possible scenarios regarding the ignition source can be considered. It is not possible to say with absolute certainty what the actual source of ignition was.</p>

Site_Description: <p>Amongst other things, the establishment processes hazardous waste. For some waste streams, rotary furnaces are used. These furnaces can be fed in various ways. One of these ways is from storage tanks. At the time of the accident, these tanks were being filled from tankers. This transfer takes place via a discharge pit.</p>
Installation_Description: <p>The discharge pits are part of the discharge installation for waste awaiting processing in the storage tanks. The waste is discharged from a tanker into the discharge pit using gravity but under low nitrogen pressure. The discharge pit is a concrete underground tank covered with a concrete lid. This discharge passes through a drum sieve to remove the solid parts from the stream using a screw. The waste stream is pumped from these discharge pits into the tanks in the tank farm. This pumping starts during the discharge from the tanker and stops automatically if the level in the discharge pit is low. The discharge pits are never completely emptied. Calculations show that around 500-700 litres of the previous load remains in the discharge pit. In order to prevent possible ingress of oxygen into the installation, the storage tanks in the tank farm, the discharge pits and the drum sieves are connected to a displacement gas network. Everything in the vapour phase is interconnected via this displacement gas network, which provides a slight excess pressure. This displacement gas network is not intended to be an inertisation system. The displacement gas network operates between 8 mbar and 12 mbar overpressure. At 12 mbar an automatic shut-off valve to the furnace is opened. At that time, the gases are sent to the furnace, where they are incinerated. At 8 mbar the shut-off valve to the furnace is closed again. In order to maintain the pressure in this system, nitrogen is added to the displacement gas system if the pressure drops below 5 mbar. There are three pressure gauges in the displacement gas network. Of these, PT90010 regulates the pressure between 8 mbar and 12 mbar, and PT90009 ensures the minimum pressure of 5 mbar in the displacement gas network. There is also a pressure gauge at the furnace (PT901), but no automatic actions are connected to this.</p>

Description:
<p>An explosion occurred during the accident. Before an explosion can occur, there must be ‘fuel’, oxygen and a source of ignition. Given the characteristics of the waste streams, it can be considered that ‘fuel’ was present. Further investigation showed that a two-step redox reaction between succinonitrile and hydrogen peroxide led to oxygen being formed. Laboratory examination has shown that, for this reaction to occur, rapid mixing must take place and the environment must be basic. All these aspects were present at the time of the accident. The previous discharge into the discharge pit was a mixture in which a succinonitrile compound was present. The pH of this mixture is 9, meaning that the environment was basic. The tanker that was being unloaded at the time of the explosion contained various IBCs with different waste liquids. Two of these IBCs contained peroxides. These peroxides accumulated in the lowest aqueous layer in the tanker. A difference in densities of the products of the IBCs had led to the formation of two layers (oil above an aqueous layer) in the tanker. The content of the IBCs concerned was in the aqueous layer that was discharged first given that the tanker is unloaded from the bottom. The speed of the discharge from the tanker led to a sufficiently rapid mixing in the discharge pit to allow the reaction to occur. Further analysis of this reaction showed that 20-30&nbsp;m³ of oxygen was formed during this reaction. This explains the formation of the explosive atmosphere in the discharge pit and the displacement gas network.</p>
<p>The IBCs with the product containing hydrogen peroxide contained only a limited amount of hydrogen peroxide and were not classified as a hazardous substance.</p>

CausesExternals.ItemDescription: utilities failure (electricity, gas, water, steam air, etc.)

Consequence_Description:
<p>The explosion destroyed the discharge pit and caused enormous damage to the transfer station. Moreover, one operator died as a result of the explosion and four other persons were slightly injured. These slight injuries were caused by a pressure wave and by flying debris. The slightly injured persons have fully recovered. One of the persons who was slightly injured is the operator who helped the person who was killed to perform the operations for connecting a pump. He was injured by flying debris. The other victims are drivers who were present in the vicinity of the discharge pits. Two discharge pits (North and South) are present on the site and are located close to each other. Two of these drivers were by their tanker, which was being unloaded at that time. Each tanker is unloaded into a different discharge pit. In addition, another driver was passing by the discharge pits at the time of the explosion. He is thought to have been carrying his papers and passed by just as the explosion occurred. The drivers involved suffered temporary damage to their hearing as well as injuries caused by flying debris.</p>
<p>4 persons who suffered hearing damage and slight injuries from flying debris.</p>

HumanOnSite.Effect: 4 persons who suffered hearing damage and slight injuries from flying debris
